tag.usage: Abbreviation identifies an abbreviation (usually in a note or introduction).
Alluded Text identifies text that is an allusion to a passage, usually from the Old Testament.
Alternate Reading identifies an alternate translation for a passage in a note.
Attribution identifies the speaker (usually the Lord) when it is in the original text.
Book Title In Text identifies a book title in the text or in the introduction.
Canonical Reference identifies a book-chapter-verse reference.
Caption identifies the caption of a picture (for example, an illustration or map).
Chapter Head identifies a heading that contains the chapter number and the word for Chapter or Psalm.
Chapter Number identifies the start of a chapter.
Chapter Number Alternate identifies the start of a chapter using an alternate numbering system (for example, Hebrew).
Citation Paragraph identifies a paragraph of prose that is quoted, usually from the Old Testament.
Closing identifies a paragraph that names the author of a communication.
Congregational Response identifies the part that the congregation speaks in a liturgical work.
Cross-Reference identifies canonical (book-chapter-verse) cross-references for a passage.
Doxology identifies a line that glorifies God.
Embedded Text Closing identifies a paragraph that names the author of a communication that is embedded in the main text.
Embedded Text Line1 identifies a first-level line that is embedded in the main text.
Embedded Text Line2 identifies a second-level line that is embedded in the main text.
Embedded Text Line3 identifies a third-level line that is embedded in the main text.
Embedded Text Opening identifies the formal beginning of a letter that is embedded in the main text.
Embedded Text Paragraph identifies a paragraph of prose that is embedded in the main text.
Embedded Text Paragraph Continuation identifies the continuation of a paragraph of prose that is embedded in the main text.
Embedded Text Refrain identifies repeated text that is embedded in the main text.
Emphasis identifies words or phrases that are stressed or emphasized for linguistic or rhetorical effect.
Foreign identifies text in a different language that has no other identifying feature.
Gloss identifies a simple definition of a word or phrase in the text.
Glossary Definition identifies a definition in the Glossary.
Glossary Entry Main identifies a main entry in the Glossary.
Glossary Entry Secondary identifies a subentry in the Glossary.
Hand identifies text that is written by a person different from the scribe writing the letter.
Header identifies the generated text at the top of each page, but you never apply it to a paragraph in the translated Scripture.
Hebrew Title identifies a title that is in the original Hebrew text.
Hyperlink identifies links to other material via URLs
Inscription identifies the text of an inscription.
Inscription Paragraph identifies a paragraph of an inscription.
Interlude identifies a line that suggests a pause to reflect.
Intro Citation Line1 identifies a first-level line that is quoted in the introduction.
Intro Citation Line2 identifies a second-level line that is quoted in the introduction.
Intro Citation Paragraph identifies a paragraph of prose that is quoted in the introduction.
Intro Cross-Reference identifies the canonical (book-chapter-verse) reference for a quoted passage in the introduction.
Intro List Item1 identifies a first-level item in a list in the introduction.
Intro List Item2 identifies a second-level item in a list in the introduction.
Intro List Item3 identifies a third-level item in a list in the introduction.
Intro Paragraph identifies a paragraph of prose in the introduction.
Intro Section Head identifies the start of a normal section in the introduction.
Intro Title Main identifies a main title in the introduction.
Intro Title Secondary identifies a part of the title that is of second-level importance in the introduction.
Intro Title Tertiary identifies a part of the title that is of third-level importance in the introduction.
Key Word identifies a word or phrase that is important for translation consistency.
Label identifies text that is a type of heading.
Line1 identifies a first-level line.
Line2 identifies a second-level line.
Line3 identifies a third-level line.
List Item1 identifies a first-level item in a list.
List Item1 Additional identifies an additional paragraph of prose in a first-level item in a list.
List Item2 identifies a second-level item in a list.
List Item2 Additional identifies an additional paragraph of prose in a second-level item in a list.
List Item3 identifies a third-level item in a list.
Mentioned identifies words, phrases, or letters that are mentioned, not used.
Name Of God identifies the name of God when the original Hebrew text is YHWH.
Normal is a parent style that other paragraph styles are based on, but you never apply it to a paragraph in the translated Scripture.
Annotation Tag is an internal style used for labeling texts in the annotation view.
Note Cross-Reference Paragraph identifies a note that contains canonical (book-chapter-verse) cross-references.
Note General Paragraph identifies a note.
Note Marker identifies the location of a note (for example, a footnote).
Note Target Reference identifies the verse (or range of verses) that is referenced in a note.
Ordinal Number Ending identifies an abbreviation for the ending of an ordinal number.
Paragraph identifies a paragraph of prose.
Paragraph Continuation identifies the continuation of a paragraph of prose.
Parallel Passage Reference identifies canonical (book-chapter-verse) references to parallel passages.
Quoted Text identifies less than a complete line or paragraph that is quoted, usually from the Old Testament.
Referenced Text identifies the text that is referenced in a note (that is, words from the text that the note is about).
Refrain identifies a line that is repeated.
Remark identifies a private note by the translator.
Section Head identifies the start of a normal section.
Section Head Major identifies the start of a major section.
Section Head Minor identifies the start of a subsection.
Section Head Series identifies the start of a section in a list of sections.
Section Range Paragraph identifies the chapter-verse range of a major section on a separate line.
See In Glossary identifies words that are defined in the Glossary.
So Called identifies text where the author or narrator of the original text distances himself from the words in question without attributing them to any other voice in particular.
Speech Line1 identifies a first-level line that is spoken by a particular speaker, usually in drama (for example, in Job and Song of Solomon).
Speech Line2 identifies a second-level line that is spoken by a particular speaker, usually in drama (for example, in Job and Song of Solomon).
Speech Speaker identifies the speaker (usually in drama) in a heading when it is not in the original text.
Stanza Break identifies the break (blank line) between stanzas of poetry.
Supplied identifies words that are not literally in the original text, but that are supplied to make the original meaning clear.
Table Cell identifies a cell in a table.
Table Cell Head identifies a cell that contains a heading in a table.
Table Cell Head Last identifies the last cell in a row that contains a heading in a table.
Table Cell Last identifies the last cell in a row in a table.
Table Row identifies the start of a row in a table.
Title Main identifies the main title of a book.
Title Secondary identifies a part of the title that is of second-level importance.
Title Tertiary identifies a part of the title that is of third-level importance.
Untranslated Word identifies vernacular words in a back translation that are not translated into the analysis language.
Variant identifies a textual reading in a note that can be regarded as part of the text, but textual scholarship cannot be taken as certain.
Variant Paragraph identifies a textual reading that can be regarded as part of the text, but textual scholarship cannot be taken as certain.
Variant Section Head identifies the start of a long variant passage.
Variant Section Tail identifies the end of a long variant passage.
Verse Number identifies the start of a verse.
Verse Number Alternate identifies the start of a verse using an alternate numbering system (for example, Hebrew).
Verse Number In Note identifies the start of a verse in a note.
Words Of Christ identifies words or phrases that are spoken by Jesus.
